title: Argos defence banding like brothers
text:
Argos coach Scott Milanovich backing QB Trevor Harris TORONTO - 
Cleyon Laing has emerged as a big-time player along the Argos’ defensive line — tough as nails and sometimes plays past the whistle, which isn’t so bad in football. 
Laing and Tristan Okpalaugo lead the team in sacks, but the entire defensive unit has stepped up as the Argos head into Saturday’s meeting against Calgary, having won three in a row. 
When the Argos began their mini-run of success, it followed a bye week after a loss to Edmonton, then dropping a home-and- home against Hamilton. 
Part of Toronto’s turnaround involves Laing and his linemates, a diverse group of young and old, Americans and Canadians, soft-spoken characters and players such as Laing and Ricky Foley who tell it like it is, whether people like it or not. 
The unit has applied pressure from the outside and inside, been assignment sound and, for the most part, discplined, which Laing believes has taken time to develop. 
“I think at the beginning of the season, we were all trying to do our own thing,’’ he said. 
“The last couple of weeks, we’ve come together. 
“In Ottawa, the onus was to contain Henry Burris. What we got was containment from the defensive ends and the two interior linemen were pressuring up the middle. It’s been a mentality of working off each other, working with each other, getting off the ball, winning those one-on-one battles when they are available. That’s what has helped us for sure.” 
The Argos like to rotate their bodies as a way to keep them fresh in the fourth quarter. 
There’s been stability and continuity with Canadians Laing and Foley and rookies Daryl Waud and Cam Walker, Americans Okpalaugo, Martin Wright and Euclid Cummings. 
Defensive co-ordinator Casey Creehan, who also oversees the defensive line, has shown a knack for calling the right blitz scheme at the right moment, the latest example provided in Monday’s win at Montreal when linebacker Thomas Miles came free off the edge to sack Rakeem Cato. 
When four down linemen are controlling the line of scrimmage and pressuring the backfield, it’s a luxury for any co-ordinator. 
Laing feels that none of his defensive linemen are afraid to speak their mind when something needs to be aired. 
“We’re always talking,’’ said Laing. “We’re a band of brothers. We fight like brothers, but we also go to war like brothers. We’ve definitely taken an open eye from the criticism we get from each other and we’re working with it.” 
Stampeders’ Bo Levi Mitchell is a big-armed quarterback, one of many elite passers Laing has had to face. 
“We have respect for him, like we do every quarterback we face every week,’’ he said. “To say he instills fear or am I worried about him, yes, he is a great quarterback. 
“But I feel I play my best when I’m comfortable with my opponent knowing I’ve prepared as much as I can.” 
IT'S SIMPLE: WIN AND THEY'RE IN 
There’s not much to dissect as the Argos venture into the Hammer to play a home game not many are likely to attend on Saturday against Calgary. 
For the Argos, a win and they are in the post-season following last year’s non-playoff appearance, the first under head coach Scott Milanovich. 
There are other scenarios and combinations, namely losses by Montreal and B.C., but it’s pretty clear cut in terms of what the Argos need to do to book their ticket to the CFL’s post-season dance. 
A year ago, the Argos lost control of their destiny when they lost a game in Montreal in the next-to-last kickoff, hoping then to have the Alouettes beat the hometown Ticats. 
When Hamilton prevailed, the Argos were toast. 
The Stamps are the only opponent Toronto will face in the coming weeks that features a winning record with games against Montreal, B.C., and Winnipeg on the horizon to close out the regular season.
